questions.question: Electric vehicle charging equipment must be supplied by what type of branch circuit?
options: A dedicated branch circuit for each EVSE
questions.explanation: Per NEC 625.40, the electric vehicle charging system shall be supplied by an individual branch circuit that supplies no other loads.

questions.question: What is the continuous load calculation for an electric vehicle charging circuit?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 625.41, for EVSE rated as a continuous load, the branch circuit conductors and overcurrent protection shall be sized at 125% of the maximum load.

questions.question: EVSE cord sets shall not exceed what length?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 625.17(B), EVSE cords shall not exceed the length specified in the listing for the equipment.

questions.question: What ventilation is required for indoor electric vehicle charging areas?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 625.52, ventilation shall be provided for indoor sites in accordance with the mechanical code and manufacturer instructions.

questions.question: The maximum voltage for EVSE equipment in dwelling units is typically what?
questions.explanation: EVSE in dwelling units can operate at voltages up to 600 volts, though common residential installations use 240V single-phase.

questions.question: Article 680 requires all underwater pool luminaires to operate at what maximum voltage unless listed for higher voltage?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.23(A)(3), no underwater luminaire shall be installed for operation on supply circuits over 15 volts between conductors, unless specifically listed for higher voltages.

questions.question: Pool equipotential bonding grid conductors shall be not smaller than what size?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.26(C), equipotential bonding for pools shall be provided using solid copper conductors, insulated, covered, or bare, not smaller than 8 AWG.

questions.question: The equipotential bonding grid for a permanently installed pool must extend horizontally how far from the inside walls?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.26(B)(1), perimeter surfaces shall extend for 3 feet (1.0m) horizontally beyond the inside walls of the pool.

questions.question: Pool pump motors must be protected by what?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.21(C), all outlets supplying pool pump motors shall be provided with Class A GFCI protection.

questions.question: What is the minimum distance required between a receptacle and the inside wall of a permanently installed pool?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.22(A)(1), receptacles shall be located not less than 6 feet (1.8m) from the inside walls of a pool.

questions.question: At least one receptacle is required within what distance of the inside wall of a permanent pool?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.22(A)(3), at least one receptacle outlet shall be located between 6 feet (1.8m) and 20 feet (6.0m) from the inside wall of the pool.

questions.question: Luminaires, lighting outlets, and ceiling-suspended paddle fans must be at least how far horizontally from the inside walls of a pool?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.22(B)(1), luminaires, lighting outlets, and ceiling-suspended paddle fans shall be located at least 5 feet (1.5m) horizontally from the inside walls of a pool.

questions.question: What NEC article covers hazardous (classified) locations?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 500 covers general requirements for electrical equipment and wiring in hazardous (classified) locations.

questions.question: Class I locations contain what type of hazard?
options: Flammable gases, flammable liquid-produced vapors, or combustible liquid-produced vapors
questions.explanation: Per NEC 500.5(B), Class I locations are those in which flammable gases, flammable liquid-produced vapors, or combustible liquid-produced vapors are or may be present.

questions.question: Class II locations contain what type of hazard?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 500.5(C), Class II locations are those that are hazardous because of the presence of combustible dust.

questions.question: Class III locations contain what type of hazard?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 500.5(D), Class III locations are those that are hazardous because of the presence of easily ignitable fibers or flyings.

questions.question: Division 1 locations are where hazardous conditions exist under what circumstances?
options: Under normal operating conditions, or frequently during maintenance
questions.explanation: Per NEC 500.5, Division 1 locations are those where ignitable concentrations of hazardous materials exist under normal operating conditions or frequently during repair or maintenance.

questions.question: Division 2 locations are where hazardous conditions exist under what circumstances?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 500.5, Division 2 locations are those where ignitable concentrations are handled, processed, or used, but under normal conditions are confined within closed systems and might be released only through abnormal operation or failure.

questions.question: What wiring method is commonly required in Class I, Division 1 locations?
options: Threaded rigid metal conduit or MI cable
questions.explanation: Per NEC 501.10(A), wiring methods in Class I, Division 1 locations shall be threaded rigid metal conduit, threaded steel intermediate metal conduit, MI cable, or other approved methods.

questions.question: Sealing fittings are required in hazardous location conduit systems to prevent what?
options: Passage of gases, vapors, or flames from one portion to another
questions.explanation: Per NEC 501.15, sealing fittings are required to prevent the passage of gases, vapors, or flames from one portion of the electrical installation to another through the conduit.

questions.question: What NEC article covers motor fuel dispensing facilities (gas stations)?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 514 covers locations where gasoline or other volatile flammable liquids or liquefied flammable gases are transferred to fuel tanks of vehicles.

questions.question: Commercial garages where flammable fuels are dispensed or repaired fall under what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 511 covers commercial garages used for service and repair operations on vehicles using volatile flammable liquids for fuel.

questions.question: What NEC article covers bulk storage plants for flammable liquids?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 515 covers areas where flammable liquids are received by tank vessel, pipelines, tank car, or tank vehicle and are stored or blended in bulk for distribution.

questions.question: Spray application, dipping, coating, and printing processes are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 516 covers locations where flammable liquids, combustible liquids, or combustible powders are applied by spray operations and other processes.

questions.question: Agricultural buildings housing livestock are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 547 covers agricultural buildings and the associated electrical systems in areas of buildings or adjacent areas where excessive dust and dust with water, corrosive atmosphere, or a combination of these exist.

questions.question: What type of equipment grounding conductor is permitted in agricultural buildings with corrosive environments?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 547.5(F), equipment grounding conductors in agricultural buildings with corrosive atmospheres shall be copper or copper-clad.

questions.question: Mobile homes and manufactured housing are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 550 covers the electrical conductors and equipment installed within or on mobile homes and manufactured homes.

questions.question: What is the minimum service or feeder for a mobile home?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 550.32, a mobile home service shall be rated at not less than 100 amperes at 120/240 volts.

questions.question: Recreational vehicles (RVs) are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 551 covers the electrical conductors and equipment for recreational vehicles.

questions.question: The standard 30-amp RV power supply connection uses what type of plug configuration?
questions.explanation: The standard 30-amp, 125-volt recreational vehicle power supply uses the NEMA TT-30P plug configuration.

questions.question: RV parks and campgrounds are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 552 covers electrical equipment and installations in park trailers and recreational vehicle parks.

questions.question: Floating buildings are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 553 covers floating buildings and the electrical installation for floating buildings.

questions.question: Marinas and boatyards are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 555 covers the installation of wiring and equipment in marinas, boatyards, boat basins, and similar occupancies.

questions.question: Shore power receptacles for boats must be protected by what?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 555.3, power outlets supplying shore power to boats shall have GFCI protection for 125V and 15, 20, or 30-amp circuits, or GFPE for larger circuits.

questions.question: Temporary wiring for construction sites is covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 590 covers temporary electrical power and lighting installations.

questions.question: Temporary wiring installations are permitted for what maximum time period?
options: The period of construction, remodeling, maintenance, repair, or demolition
questions.explanation: Per NEC 590.3(A), temporary electrical power and lighting installations shall be permitted during the period of construction, remodeling, maintenance, repair, or demolition of buildings.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required on temporary wiring construction sites for what circuits?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 590.6(A), all 125-volt, single-phase, 15-, 20-, and 30-ampere receptacle outlets used for temporary power during construction shall have GFCI protection.

questions.question: Article 700 emergency systems must restore power within what time frame?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.12(B), emergency systems shall automatically restore power within 10 seconds of interruption of the normal supply.

questions.question: What NEC article covers legally required standby systems?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 701 covers legally required standby systems, which are those required by codes to provide power to selected loads in the event of normal power failure.

questions.question: Legally required standby systems must restore power within what time frame?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 701.12(B), legally required standby systems shall have power available within 60 seconds of failure of the normal power source.

questions.question: What NEC article covers optional standby systems?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 702 covers optional standby systems that provide power for selected loads when the normal supply fails.

questions.question: Optional standby systems are those intended to supply what types of loads?
options: Loads where life safety does not depend on the system
questions.explanation: Per NEC 702.2, optional standby systems are intended to supply power to public or private facilities or property where life safety does not depend on the performance of the system.

questions.question: What NEC article covers interconnected electric power production sources?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 705 covers the installation of one or more electric power production sources operating in parallel with a primary source(s) of electricity.

questions.question: Solar photovoltaic systems are covered by what NEC article?
questions.explanation: NEC Article 690 covers solar photovoltaic (PV) electrical energy systems, including the array circuit(s), inverter(s), and controller(s).

questions.question: What is the maximum voltage for most residential solar PV systems?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.7, PV systems for other than dwelling units are permitted up to 1000 volts. Dwelling unit PV systems are typically limited to 600 volts.

questions.question: PV system circuit conductors must be sized at what percentage of maximum current?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.9, PV source circuit and output circuit conductor ampacity shall be not less than 125% of the maximum current.

questions.question: What type of disconnecting means is required for PV systems?
options: A means to disconnect all current-carrying conductors from all sources simultaneously
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.15, means shall be provided to disconnect all current-carrying dc conductors of a PV system from all other conductors in a building or structure.

questions.question: PV system disconnects must be located where?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.15, the PV system disconnecting means shall be installed at a readily accessible location.

questions.question: What labeling is required for a building with a PV system?
options: Warning sign at service indicating PV system present
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.56, a permanent plaque or directory identifying the PV system shall be installed at or near the service equipment and at each normal power source disconnect.

questions.question: Energy storage systems (batteries) connected to PV systems are covered by what article in addition to Article 690?
questions.explanation: Energy storage systems are covered by Article 706 for ESS requirements and Article 480 for stationary battery installations, in addition to Article 690 for PV-connected systems.
